header_1: LPAI H7N9 in Wild birds in China
content_1: .  Fear of another outbreak of the H7N9 bird flu virus was heightened after two wild geese were found dead at the Shanghai Zoo earlier this week; however, officials confirmed that the two birds actually died of intestinal inflammation and hepatitis.  To date, 33 H7N9 cases and 15 deaths have been confirmed in Shanghai to bring the total to 132 cases with 38 deaths.  The most recent victim, a 59-year-old man, died on May 31st after being diagnosed at the beginning of April.
header_2: LPAI H7 in Poultry in Denmark
content_2: .  The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration confirmed an outbreak of low pathogenic avian influenza H7 on May 31st on a mallard and pheasant farm in Viborg, a city in central Jutland, Denmark.  Because the birds are separated epidemiologically, the 1,400 infected mallards will be culled as soon as possible while the remaining 12,500 pheasants will be closely monitored and tested for the virus.  Additionally, a restricted zone has been established around the farm in the hope that the disease will be prevented from spreading.
header_3: LPAI H7 in Poultry in The Netherlands
content_3: .  The Dutch Economic Affairs Ministry confirmed an outbreak of LPAI H7N1 on a farm in Leusden, in the Province of Utrecht, earlier this week.  To prevent the disease from spreading further, all 11,000 free-range chickens at the infected farm will be culled.  Additionally, nearby farms are being tested for the virus and a ban on the transport of poultry, eggs, and other farm products has been initiated.
